moves.1. e4: The opening is boring until I make a mistake.
moves.5... Ng4: Not paying enough attention, my knight commits suicide.
moves.6. Qxg4: The Queen begins and attack, backed by the developed white bishop.
moves.7... d6: I confront the pawn and uncover an attack on White's Queen.
moves.8. Qf3: His retreat opens a checkmate threat on f7.
moves.8... O-O: I castle to protect the pawn and guard the King.
moves.9. Bxh6: White takes a free pawn, attacking the rook that I cannot move, but this is where I turn the game around for a fairly quick checkmate.
moves.9... Qh4+: Knowing that I can't defend the rook, I put White in check and position myself to capture the menacing bishop.
moves.10. g3: With no way to save the bishop. White puts a pawn in the way.
moves.10... Qxh6: Some pressure is taken off of my king, and the rook is saved.
moves.11. Nd5: Seeing no need to protect his king any further, White begins a new attack that I cannot stop.
moves.11... Nc6: I choose to counter attack and simultaneously leave my rook room to escape the knight's predictable next move.
moves.12. Nxc7: White ignores my advance, and takes the pawn.  The beginning of the end.
moves.12... Nd4: My knight safely moves to put his queen in check while positioning itself to fork the king and rook unless his queen defends pawn c2.
moves.13. Qd1: With few available options, White's queen goes back home, allowing my Queen to come in to attack.
moves.13... Qe3+: White can either surrender his queen to my knight or walk into checkmate by putting his knight in the way.
moves.14. Ne2: Unable to part with his Queen, he makes his second to last move.
moves.14... Nf3+: Now the king has nowhere to go but f1.
moves.15. Kf1: I could end the game by moving the Queen to f2 or bringing my white bishop down to h3, which I found to be more interesting.
moves.15... Bh3#: Somehow, the game I should have lost turned around in my favor.   I've won even though I only captured one of his pieces and lost a knight and three pawns.
